comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: A tramwayman's funeral on the same site c.1934. Note the tram signal box atop Newtown Station. I wonder when the station lost its weather vane? [see photosau.com.au/Cos/scripts/home.asp > Search for: 056032]

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: If you look at a contemporary view of the station building on Google Street View, it is remarkably intact, although still no weather vane. maps.google.com.au/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&...

comment.author: 25550875@N02
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Sembra incredibile ma....eravamo così!!!, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: A new station concourse is currently under construction down the side of this building, including a bridge over to the centre (lengthwise) of the platform. The building in the picture will become leased retail and no longer part of the station facilities.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Thanks for the update. If you ever get to take a 'now' photo to compare with this 'then' photo please let us know.

AB

comment.author: 57407120@N07
comment._content:
Can anyone answer why they are "relaying" the tram tracks. Looks to be a massive job being undertaken

Ric

comment.author: 93390496@N03
comment._content:
We have nearly finished restoring the old booking office at Newtown Station. One of the last things to do is install a new weathervane that matches the original one seen in the photo. Once works are complete I will post a photo from a similar angle to compare the difference. 

My favourite thing about this photo above is right in the centre you can see three ladies attempt to walk over the tram tracks in their long dresses.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/93390496@N03] Thanks Red. We'll await with interest.
